thread.title: Is this Walking Dead t-shirt racist? Primark pulls item following complaint
thread.title_full: Is this Walking Dead t-shirt racist? Primark pulls item following complaint

author: Adam Boult
title: Is this Walking Dead t-shirt racist? Primark pulls item following complaint
text:
Is this Walking Dead t-shirt racist? Primark pulls item following complaint A t-shirt similar to the item withdrawn by Primark Credit: Amazon Adam Boult 21 February 2017 • 4:45pm 
A Walking Dead t-shirt, featuring a quote and image from the US TV show, has been withdrawn from sale at Primark after a customer complained it was 'racist'. 
The shirt was emblazoned with the words 'Eeny Meeny Miny Moe', along with a picture of a baseball bat, in reference to an episode of The Walking Dead in which a character says the phrase before beating a character to death. 
Shopper Ian Lucraft told the Sheffield Star he first spotted the item while shopping with his wife. He said: "We were shocked when we came face to face with a new t-shirt with a racially explicit graphic and text. 
"It was fantastically offensive and I can only assume that no-one in the process of ordering it knew what they were doing or were aware of its subliminal messages. Primark pulls "shocking" and "racist" Walking Dead t-shirt from stores after Sheffield man's angry complaint... https://t.co/EJah0VNs3u pic.twitter.com/3X8mawMNyf — The Star, Sheffield (@SheffieldStar) 21 February 2017 
"The slogan is “Eeeny meenie miny moe...” It stops there, but of course we all know what the original said: 'catch a n by his toe.' 
"The graphic has a large American baseball bat, wrapped round with barbed wire, and covered with blood. This image relates directly to the practice of assaulting black people in America. 
"It is directly threatening of a racist assault, and if I were black and were faced by a wearer I would know just where I stood." Watch | The Walking Dead season 7 trailer 03:06 
'Eeeny meenie miny moe' has been in existence as a counting-out rhyme since at least the early 20th century, in various iterations. While the use of the N-word was once commonplace, it has generally been replaced with 'Tiger' where the rhyme is still used. 
I n the episode of The Walking Dead the t-shirt refers to, the character who says the rhyme uses the 'Catch a tiger by toe' version. 
Mr Lucraft submitted his complaint directly to Primark Chief Executive Paul Marchant, saying: "I assume that with some past incidents that I see have happened with Primark goods, you are anxious to prevent further bad publicity, and do not want to offend other shoppers. Jeffrey Dean Morgan as Negan in The Walking Dead Credit: Gene Page/AMC via AP 
"I can see that your website is strong on corporate responsibility so I hope you will take this t-shirt off sale immediately." 
A spokesman for Primark said: “The t-shirt in question is licensed merchandise for the U.S. television series, The Walking Dead, and the quote and image are taken directly from the show. 

“Any offence caused by its design was wholly unintentional and Primark sincerely apologises for this. 

“Primark has removed the product from sale.” Watch | Primark to set the trend in US 01:58
